roots.notes: One of the most productive Latin roots; appears in over 20 common English words. Great entry point because the meaning is concrete and easy to illustrate.
Also appears as 'vid' (video, evidence). Pair with 'aud' (hear) for contrast. The 'v' onset is consistent across forms, making it easier to spot.
Consonant cluster 'rupt' is phonetically regular. The concept of 'breaking' something is accessible and motivating for students.
Two forms: 'scrib' before a vowel suffix, 'script' before a consonant suffix. Teach both forms together. Connects to 'prescription' and 'subscription' which students encounter.
Highly productive. Connects directly to 'dictionary,' which students use daily. The 'd' initial consonant is stable across all derived forms.
Consonant cluster 'str' at the front is a reliable cue. The meaning 'build' is concrete. 'Instruction' is a school word students hear constantly.
Short and phonetically simple. Excellent bridge root because students already know 'act' as a standalone word. Very high frequency in academic contexts.
Students already know 'form' as a word. Extend to the idea of 'shaping' something. 'Uniform' (one shape/appearance) is a vivid example.
Two forms: 'mit' in verbs (submit, transmit), 'miss' in nouns (mission, permission). Teach the pattern explicitly. 'Permission' and 'submit' are high-value school words.
Phonetically stable. The school setting provides natural examples: auditorium, audio, audition. Pairs well with 'vis' (see) for a contrast lesson.
Two forms. 'Inspect' and 'expect' are common school and everyday words. The idea of 'looking carefully' is concrete and memorable.
Short root, easy to isolate. 'Transfer' connects to 'transport' (both mean carry). 'Prefer' (carry before = choose first) and 'refer' (carry back) are academic vocabulary.

prefixes.notes: Most common prefix in English academic vocabulary. Easy to teach because the spelling never changes. Caution: 'reach' and 'read' are not re- + root. Teach boundary explicitly.
Second most common prefix. Always attaches to adjectives or past participles. Spelling never changes. Contrast with 'in-/im-/ir-' which also mean 'not' but are Latin-origin.
Highly transparent meaning. 'Pretest' and 'preview' are school words students know. The 'e' in 'pre' is long and consistent, making it phonetically reliable.
Has two meanings: 'not' (disagree) and 'apart/away' (disrupt). Teach 'not' meaning first. Spelling is consistent. Caution: 'dish' and 'disc' are not dis- + root.

Spelling changes before certain consonants: 'im-' before p/b/m (impossible, imbalance). Teach the pattern as a rule. High academic utility. Also means 'into' in some words — teach 'not' meaning first.
Spelling is consistent. The meaning 'across' is concrete and visual. Use a map to illustrate: transatlantic = across the Atlantic. High utility in science and social studies.

Meaning 'under' is concrete (submarine = under the sea). 'Subtract' is a math term students know. Caution: 'sub' in 'submit' means 'under/up to,' a slightly different nuance — teach after the core meaning is solid.
Longer prefix but spelling is always consistent. 'Interrupt' (break between) and 'interact' (do between) are high-frequency school words. Use 'internet' (between networks) as a hook.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a verb into a noun
suffixes.notes: Most common nominalizing suffix in English. Spelling: -tion after most roots, -sion after roots ending in 'd' or 's' (permission, discussion). Pronunciation: always /shun/. Teach with a verb-to-noun flip chart.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a verb into a noun
suffixes.notes: Very regular: just add -ment. No spelling changes in most cases. Base word is often still visible (move → movement), making it easy for students to see the transformation. High academic utility.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns an adjective into a noun
suffixes.notes: Very regular Germanic suffix. Base word clearly visible. Double the final consonant if the adjective ends in a short vowel + consonant (sadness from sad). Great starting suffix for younger or lower grades.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a noun into an adjective
suffixes.notes: Spelling is always -ful (one l, not full). Highly regular. Base word is always clear. Contrast with '-less' (without) to teach as a pair.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a noun into an adjective
suffixes.notes: Perfect contrast suffix with '-ful.' Teach as a pair: careful/careless, helpful/helpless. Spelling is always -less. Base word is fully preserved. Concrete, easy to demonstrate with examples.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a verb or noun into an adjective
suffixes.notes: Two spellings: -able (more common, usually with whole base words: readable) and -ible (usually with Latin roots: visible, flexible). Teach -able first. High academic utility. Builds directly on root meanings (vis + ible = able to be seen).

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a verb into a noun (agent noun)
suffixes.notes: -er is native English (teacher, runner); -or is Latin (actor, director). For MVP, teach as one suffix meaning 'one who.' High utility: students can build agent nouns from any verb they know. Drop silent e before -er (writer from write).

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns an adjective into an adverb
suffixes.notes: Very regular: just add -ly to an adjective. One spelling change: adjectives ending in -le drop the e and add -y (simply, gently). High frequency in academic writing. Students encounter this constantly in reading instructions and directions.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a noun into a noun (person noun)
suffixes.notes: Useful for social studies and science vocabulary (biologist, economist, activist). Regular spelling. Connects to '-ism' and '-ize' in later grades. Good for grades 5-8.

suffixes.part_of_speech_effect: turns a noun into an adjective
suffixes.notes: Latin-origin. Spelling note: some base words change (fame → famous, danger → dangerous). Pronunciation: /us/. High utility in literary and science texts. Teach after -ful since both mean 'having/full of' — contrast the origins.

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to carry something or someone from one place to another
wordCards.decoding_notes: Regular. Two clear syllables: trans | port. The 'trans-' prefix is spelled the same every time. 'Port' is the root meaning carry.
wordCards.example_sentence: The train will transport passengers to the city.
distractor_meanings: to break something into pieces
to write a message
to look at something carefully

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: easy to carry or move from place to place
wordCards.decoding_notes: Regular. Three syllables: por | ta | ble. Drop-e rule not applicable here. The 'a' in -able is unstressed — say it like 'uh-bul'.
wordCards.example_sentence: She brought a portable speaker to the picnic.
distractor_meanings: too heavy to lift
able to be seen clearly
easy to read aloud

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to bring goods into a country from another place
wordCards.decoding_notes: Stress shifts: IM-port (noun) vs. im-PORT (verb). Two syllables: im | port. 'Im-' is a form of the prefix 'in-' meaning 'into.'
wordCards.example_sentence: The store imports coffee from South America.
distractor_meanings: to send things away to another country
to write down important facts
to carry something on your back

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to carry information back; to tell about something that happened
wordCards.decoding_notes: Regular. Two syllables: re | port. 're-' means back — a report carries information back to someone. Very common school word.
wordCards.example_sentence: She will report her findings to the class.
distractor_meanings: to hide information from others
to predict what will happen
to break something apart

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: able to be seen
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: vis | i | ble. The 'i' in the middle is short. Uses -ible (not -able) because it attaches directly to the Latin root 'vis.'
wordCards.example_sentence: The stars were visible on the clear night.
distractor_meanings: able to be heard clearly
able to be moved easily
able to be written down

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: not able to be seen
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: in | vis | i | ble. 'In-' here means 'not.' The root 'vis' (see) is in the middle. Good for showing how a prefix changes meaning completely.
wordCards.example_sentence: The ink was invisible until you held the paper up to light.
distractor_meanings: very easy to see
not able to be heard
not able to be moved

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to look at your work again and make it better
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: re | vise. Silent 'e' at the end makes the 'i' long. 're-' (again) + 'vis' (see) = see again. Very relevant school vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: She revised her essay after the teacher gave feedback.
distractor_meanings: to read something for the first time
to copy someone else's work
to break a rule

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to watch over others to make sure things are done correctly
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: su | per | vise. 'Super-' means over/above. 'Vis' means see. To supervise = to see over/above. The silent 'e' makes the 'i' long.
wordCards.example_sentence: The coach will supervise the players during practice.
distractor_meanings: to listen carefully to a group
to write instructions for others
to carry supplies to a team

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to break in on what someone is doing or saying
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | ter | rupt. Double consonant at the end: -rrupt. 'Inter-' (between) + 'rupt' (break) = break between. Common classroom management word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Please do not interrupt while someone else is speaking.
distractor_meanings: to listen carefully to someone
to carry a message between two people
to write notes during a speech

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to burst out suddenly with great force
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: e | rupt. The 'e-' is a Latin prefix meaning 'out.' Short and phonetically regular. Great science word — volcanoes erupt.
wordCards.example_sentence: The volcano could erupt at any time.
distractor_meanings: to slowly pour out over time
to build up a strong structure
to carry rocks down a mountain

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to break apart or disturb something that was working smoothly
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: dis | rupt. 'Dis-' (apart/away) + 'rupt' (break) = break apart. The final consonant cluster -rupt should be blended as one unit.
wordCards.example_sentence: The loud noise will disrupt the students who are reading.
distractor_meanings: to repair something that is broken
to carry parts from one place to another
to write a plan for something

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: completely broken from honesty; using power in a dishonest way
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: cor | rupt. 'Cor-' is a form of 'com-' (together/completely). Together + break = completely broken. A good word for social studies discussions.
wordCards.example_sentence: The corrupt official was removed from office.
distractor_meanings: very powerful and in charge
able to be trusted completely
difficult to understand or read

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to write or tell what something looks like or how it is
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: de | scribe. Silent 'e' at the end. 'Scrib' is the form of the root used before vowel suffixes. Very common school word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Describe the main character using three words.
distractor_meanings: to draw a picture of something
to carry something to someone else
to look at something carefully

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: written instructions from a doctor about what medicine to take
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: pre | scrip | tion. 'Pre-' (before) + 'script' (write) + '-ion' (act of) = the act of writing something before. The 'c' in '-tion' is silent; it's pronounced /shun/.
wordCards.example_sentence: The doctor wrote a prescription for the patient.
distractor_meanings: a note carried between two doctors
a report written after seeing a doctor
a plan for building a hospital

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: words written or carved into a surface
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | scrip | tion. 'In-' here means 'into' (not 'not'). Writing into a surface. '-tion' = /shun/. Great for history/social studies contexts.
wordCards.example_sentence: The inscription on the trophy showed the winner's name.
distractor_meanings: a picture drawn on a wall
a note sent between two people
a story told out loud to a group

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a document written by hand or typed before it is published
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: man | u | script. 'Manu-' means hand (from Latin manus). Hand + write = written by hand. Connect to 'manual' (done by hand).
wordCards.example_sentence: The author sent her manuscript to the publisher.
distractor_meanings: a book that has already been printed and sold
a short note written on a card
a document that has been copied by a machine

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to say what you think will happen before it happens
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: pre | dict. 'Pre-' (before) + 'dict' (say) = say before. The final consonant cluster -ct should be blended. Extremely common in school reading activities.
wordCards.example_sentence: Can you predict what will happen next in the story?
distractor_meanings: to remember something that happened before
to write down an important fact
to look at something from far away

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a statement that says the opposite of what was said before
wordCards.decoding_notes: Five syllables: con | tra | dic | tion. 'Contra-' means against. Against + say + act of = the act of saying against. '-tion' = /shun/. Good for argument/debate discussions.
wordCards.example_sentence: There was a contradiction between what she said yesterday and today.
distractor_meanings: an agreement between two people
a rule written down in a document
a story that is hard to understand

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to say words out loud for someone else to write down; or to give strict orders
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: dic | tate. The 'a' in '-tate' is long due to the final 'e.' Two meanings — connect to 'dictator' for the orders meaning.
wordCards.example_sentence: The teacher will dictate the spelling words for students to write.
distractor_meanings: to read a text aloud from a page
to carry a message to a group
to draw a picture while someone watches

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to teach or give directions for how to do something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: in | struct. 'In-' here means 'into.' To build knowledge into someone. Final consonant cluster -ct should be blended as one unit.
wordCards.example_sentence: The coach will instruct the team on how to defend.
distractor_meanings: to break apart an old building
to look at something very carefully
to carry tools from place to place

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the act of building something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: con | struc | tion. 'Con-' means together. Build together = construction. '-tion' = /shun/. The consonant blend 'str' at the start of the root is the main decoding challenge.
wordCards.example_sentence: The construction of the new school took two years.
distractor_meanings: the act of tearing something down
a plan written on paper
the act of moving things to a new place

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: causing a lot of damage or harm
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: de | struc | tive. 'De-' means down/away (un-build). '-ive' is a suffix meaning tending to. The cluster 'str' in the root can be tricky — blend it as one unit.
wordCards.example_sentence: The hurricane was the most destructive storm in years.
distractor_meanings: very helpful and useful to people
built to last for a very long time
easy to move from one place to another

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the basic systems and structures a city or country needs to work, like roads and bridges
wordCards.decoding_notes: Five syllables: in | fra | struc | ture. 'Infra-' means below/beneath. The basic structure below everything. Long word — chunk it: infra + structure.
wordCards.example_sentence: The government invested money to repair the country's infrastructure.
distractor_meanings: a set of rules written for a community
a large building used for government work
a team of people hired to plan a city

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: something you do or feel in response to what happens
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: re | ac | tion. 're-' (again/back) + 'act' (do) + '-ion' (act of) = act back. '-tion' = /shun/. Very common in science (chemical reaction) and social contexts.
wordCards.example_sentence: Her reaction to the surprise party was a big smile.
distractor_meanings: a decision made before something happens
a plan written down in advance
a report describing what someone did

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to do things with others; to affect each other
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | ter | act. 'Inter-' (between) + 'act' (do) = do between/together. The prefix 'inter-' is longer but always spelled the same way.
wordCards.example_sentence: Students should interact with each other during group work.
distractor_meanings: to work alone without asking for help
to write a note to a teacher
to look at something without touching it

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: not doing anything; not moving or working
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | ac | tive. 'In-' (not) + 'act' (do) + '-ive' (tending to) = tending not to do. Contrast with 'active.' Good for science contexts (inactive volcano).
wordCards.example_sentence: The volcano has been inactive for over 200 years.
distractor_meanings: very busy and doing a lot of things
able to be moved from one place to another
working at full speed and power

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to change something to make it better
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: re | form. 're-' (again) + 'form' (shape) = shape again. Stress falls on the second syllable as a verb (re-FORM). High utility in social studies.
wordCards.example_sentence: The mayor promised to reform the school system.
distractor_meanings: to keep things exactly the same as before
to break apart an old structure
to write a new law without changing anything

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to change completely into something different
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: trans | form. 'Trans-' (across) + 'form' (shape) = change shape across. Phonetically regular. Great for science (transform energy) and ELA (characters transform).
wordCards.example_sentence: The caterpillar will transform into a butterfly.
distractor_meanings: to stay exactly the same over time
to carry something from one person to another
to write about how something looks

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the same throughout; or clothing that everyone in a group wears to look the same
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: u | ni | form. 'Uni-' means one. One shape = uniform. Stress on first syllable: U-ni-form. Students likely know this word already — now they understand why.
wordCards.example_sentence: All students wore a uniform to school.
distractor_meanings: many different shapes and colors
something that is hard to see clearly
a style that changes every year

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to send in your work or give it to someone in charge
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: sub | mit. 'Sub-' (under/up to) + 'mit' (send) = send up to. Phonetically regular. Double the 't' when adding -ing or -ed (submitted). Very common school word.
wordCards.example_sentence: You must submit your homework by Friday.
distractor_meanings: to refuse to do an assignment
to read over your work before starting
to look at someone else's answers

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to send information or signals from one place to another
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: trans | mit. 'Trans-' (across) + 'mit' (send) = send across. Science vocabulary: transmit a signal, transmit disease. Double 't' before vowel suffixes.
wordCards.example_sentence: Radio towers transmit signals across long distances.
distractor_meanings: to receive a message from far away
to store information in a safe place
to break a signal into smaller pieces

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: when someone in charge says it is okay for you to do something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: per | mis | sion. 'Per-' (through/completely) + 'miss' (send) + '-ion' = act of sending through. '-sion' = /shun/. Double 's' before -ion when root ends in 'ss.'
wordCards.example_sentence: You need permission from a parent to go on the field trip.
distractor_meanings: a plan for how to get something done
a letter written to a teacher
a list of rules you must follow

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: an important task or job that someone is sent to do
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: mis | sion. 'Miss' (send) + '-ion' (act of) = act of being sent. '-sion' = /shun/. Double 's' is the main spelling challenge. Common in science, history, and everyday language.
wordCards.example_sentence: The astronauts completed their mission to the space station.
distractor_meanings: a long journey taken for fun
a building where people go to learn
a story about someone who is lost

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a group of people who listen to or watch a performance or speech
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: au | di | ence. The 'au' diphthong is pronounced /aw/. 'Aud' (hear) — the audience listens. The final '-ience' ending can be tricky; say it: ee-ents.
wordCards.example_sentence: The audience clapped at the end of the play.
distractor_meanings: the people who perform on a stage
a group of people who write reviews
the judges who decide on a winner

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: loud enough to be heard
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: au | di | ble. 'Aud' (hear) + '-ible' (able to be) = able to be heard. The 'au' is /aw/. Contrast with 'visible' — what you can see vs. what you can hear.
wordCards.example_sentence: Her voice was barely audible from the back of the room.
distractor_meanings: able to be seen from far away
able to be moved from place to place
easy to understand when you read it

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a large room or building where people go to hear performances or speeches
wordCards.decoding_notes: Five syllables: au | di | to | ri | um. Long word — chunk it: audi + torium. 'Aud' (hear) — a place for hearing. Students encounter this word in school. Stress on the third syllable.
wordCards.example_sentence: All students gathered in the auditorium for the assembly.
distractor_meanings: a room where teachers meet to plan lessons
a large outdoor area for playing sports
a place where books and magazines are stored

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to look at something very carefully to check for problems
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: in | spect. 'In-' here means 'into.' To look into. Final consonant cluster -ct should be blended. Common in science and social studies.
wordCards.example_sentence: The engineer will inspect the bridge for cracks.
distractor_meanings: to build something from scratch
to listen carefully for sounds
to write a report about a place

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a person who watches an event without taking part in it
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: spec | ta | tor. 'Spect' (look) + '-or' (person who) = one who looks. Stress on the first syllable. Great for sports and social studies contexts.
wordCards.example_sentence: The spectators cheered when the team scored.
distractor_meanings: a person who plays in a sports game
someone who writes about a competition
a judge who decides who wins

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the way you see or think about something based on your point of view
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: per | spec | tive. 'Per-' (through) + 'spec' (look) + '-tive' = the act of looking through. '-tive' ending: stress falls on the syllable before it. Critical thinking vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: From her perspective, the rule seemed unfair.
distractor_meanings: a decision made without thinking carefully
a fact that everyone agrees on
a list of reasons why something happened

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to move or carry something from one place or person to another
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: trans | fer. Stress shifts: TRANS-fer (noun) vs. trans-FER (verb). 'Trans-' (across) + 'fer' (carry) = carry across. Double 'r' before vowel suffixes (transferred).
wordCards.example_sentence: She will transfer to a new school next year.
distractor_meanings: to keep something in the same place
to break something into two pieces
to look at something from a new angle

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to like one thing better than another
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: pre | fer. 'Pre-' (before) + 'fer' (carry) = carry before = choose first. Double 'r' before vowel suffixes (preferred, preferring). Very common word.
wordCards.example_sentence: I prefer chocolate ice cream over vanilla.
distractor_meanings: to dislike something very strongly
to share something equally with others
to wait before making a choice

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to send someone to another person or source; to mention or point to something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: re | fer. 're-' (back) + 'fer' (carry) = carry back. Double 'r' before vowel suffixes (referred). Common academic reading instruction word: 'refer back to the text.'
wordCards.example_sentence: Please refer to page 12 for the answer.
distractor_meanings: to ignore something that was said before
to write a new version of a document
to carry a book from one room to another

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to write something again, usually to make it better
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: re | write. 're-' (again) is the key morpheme. The base word 'write' has a silent 'w' — this is irregular. Phonetically: /rīt/. Very common school vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: The teacher asked him to rewrite his introduction.
distractor_meanings: to read something aloud to the class
to look at your work without changing it
to copy someone else's writing exactly

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: not easy to understand; confusing
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: un | clear. 'Un-' (not) added to the adjective 'clear.' Phonetically regular. 'cl-' is a common consonant blend. Base word is transparent.
wordCards.example_sentence: Her directions were unclear, so nobody knew what to do.
distractor_meanings: very detailed and easy to follow
written in very small print
too loud to understand

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: not done or completed yet
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: un | fin | ished. 'Un-' (not) + past participle of 'finish.' '-ished' = /isht/. A clear example of un- attaching to a past participle to create an adjective.
wordCards.example_sentence: He left an unfinished drawing on his desk.
distractor_meanings: done very carefully and neatly
started and completed on time
checked and approved by a teacher

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to have a different opinion from someone else
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: dis | a | gree. 'Dis-' (not) + 'agree.' The base word 'agree' is transparent. Long 'e' at the end from the double 'e.' Common in academic discussions and debates.
wordCards.example_sentence: It is okay to disagree as long as you are respectful.
distractor_meanings: to have exactly the same opinion as someone
to refuse to talk to another person
to write down your ideas without telling anyone

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to separate or break a connection between things
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: dis | con | nect. 'Dis-' (apart) + 'connect.' The base word 'connect' contains the prefix 'con-' (together). To disconnect is to undo the connecting.
wordCards.example_sentence: Please disconnect the charger before leaving the room.
distractor_meanings: to join two things together tightly
to turn on a device and make it work
to move something from one outlet to another

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to look at or watch something before the full version is shared
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: pre | view. 'Pre-' (before) + 'view' (see, from French/Latin 'vis'). Phonetically regular. Connects directly to the strategy of previewing a text before reading.
wordCards.example_sentence: We watched a preview of the movie before it was released.
distractor_meanings: to look back at something after it is done
to listen to an audio clip before deciding
to read something out loud to a partner

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a ship that travels underwater
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: sub | ma | rine. 'Sub-' (under) + 'marine' (sea, from Latin mare). The long 'e' at the end comes from French. Great hook word for the prefix 'sub-.'
wordCards.example_sentence: The submarine dove deep beneath the ocean.
distractor_meanings: a fast boat that travels on top of water
a large ship that carries goods across the ocean
a plane that can land on water

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to take away a number or amount from another
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: sub | tract. 'Sub-' (under/away) + 'tract' (pull/draw, from Latin). Pull away = subtract. The cluster '-tract' at the end is the main decoding challenge.
wordCards.example_sentence: If you subtract 4 from 10, you get 6.
distractor_meanings: to add two numbers together
to put a number in a different order
to multiply one number by another

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: between states; a highway that connects different states
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | ter | state. 'Inter-' (between) + 'state.' Highly transparent once 'inter-' is known. Stress on first syllable. Great for geography and social studies.
wordCards.example_sentence: We drove on the interstate to get from Ohio to Kentucky.
distractor_meanings: within a single town or city
above the clouds and out of reach
connected to another country by a bridge

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: not able to be done; not possible
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: im | pos | si | ble. 'Im-' (not, form of 'in-' before 'p') + 'possible.' The 'im-' spelling rule: use im- before p, b, m. Stress on second syllable.
wordCards.example_sentence: It felt impossible to finish all that work in one night.
distractor_meanings: very difficult but able to be done
easy to do without any help
something that happens every day

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: not finished or not having all its parts
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | com | plete. 'In-' (not) + 'complete.' Long 'e' at end from the final 'e.' Phonetically regular. Common feedback word in school settings.
wordCards.example_sentence: The teacher marked the assignment incomplete.
distractor_meanings: done exactly the right way
turned in before the deadline
too long and needing to be shorter

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: something that is done; the process of doing something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: ac | tion. 'Act' (do) + '-ion' = the act of doing. '-tion' = /shun/. Short, phonetically regular. Students hear and use this word constantly.
wordCards.example_sentence: Her quick action saved the puppy from the street.
distractor_meanings: a thought you have but do not carry out
a written plan for what to do later
a picture that shows what happened

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the act of moving; a group of people working together toward a goal
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: move | ment. Base word 'move' + '-ment.' Silent 'e' in 'move' is kept when adding '-ment.' Clear suffix — base word is fully visible.
wordCards.example_sentence: The civil rights movement changed the laws of the country.
distractor_meanings: a building where people gather to vote
a written rule that everyone must follow
a speech given by a famous leader

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: when two or more people share the same opinion or make a deal
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: a | gree | ment. Base word 'agree' + '-ment.' Silent 'e' in 'agree' is kept. Long 'e' sound preserved in 'agree.' Common in social studies and language arts.
wordCards.example_sentence: The two countries signed a peace agreement.
distractor_meanings: a disagreement between two groups
a rule made by only one person
a note sent to explain why someone is absent

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: something you say or write that gives information or an opinion
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: state | ment. Base word 'state' + '-ment.' Silent 'e' in 'state' is kept. Common in academic writing: thesis statement, evidence statement.
wordCards.example_sentence: The witness gave a statement to the police.
distractor_meanings: a question asked to get more information
a command that tells someone what to do
a story made up about something imaginary

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the quality of being kind and caring to others
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: kind | ness. Base word 'kind' + '-ness.' No spelling changes needed. Phonetically regular. Great anchor word for the -ness suffix.
wordCards.example_sentence: She showed kindness by helping her classmate.
distractor_meanings: the feeling of being angry at someone
the act of telling someone what to do
a quality of being very loud and cheerful

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the state of having no light; when a place or feeling is very dark
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: dark | ness. Base word 'dark' + '-ness.' No spelling change. Phonetically regular. Common in literature for setting and mood.
wordCards.example_sentence: The darkness of the cave made it hard to see.
distractor_meanings: a very bright and shiny light
the sound a room makes when it is quiet
the color of the sky just before sunset

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: knowing about or understanding something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: a | ware | ness. Base word 'aware' + '-ness.' The 'e' in 'aware' is kept before '-ness.' Stress on second syllable. Academic word used in health, social studies, and SEL.
wordCards.example_sentence: The program raised awareness about recycling.
distractor_meanings: the ability to move quickly without thinking
a feeling of not knowing what to do
the act of teaching others a new skill

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: willing to help; making things easier for others
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: help | ful. Base word 'help' + '-ful' (one 'l'). Phonetically regular. The spelling of the suffix is '-ful' not '-full' — teach this spelling rule explicitly.
wordCards.example_sentence: It is helpful to read the directions first.
distractor_meanings: making things harder or more confusing
someone who needs a lot of support
not interested in doing any work

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: having a lot of strength, force, or influence
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: pow | er | ful. Base word 'power' + '-ful.' The 'ow' in 'power' = /ow/ as in cow. Phonetically accessible. Common in science and social studies.
wordCards.example_sentence: The storm was the most powerful in a decade.
distractor_meanings: very weak and easy to break
having a lot of money but no strength
quiet and difficult to notice

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: having real importance or value; making a difference
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: mean | ing | ful. Base word 'meaning' + '-ful.' The '-ing' in 'meaning' is part of the base, not a suffix here. Stress on first syllable. Social-emotional and academic word.
wordCards.example_sentence: She wrote a meaningful letter to her grandmother.
distractor_meanings: very confusing and hard to figure out
lasting only a short amount of time
made up without a real purpose

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: without a home or place to live
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: home | less. Base word 'home' + '-less.' Silent 'e' in 'home' is kept before '-less.' Phonetically regular. Social studies context; sensitive — frame discussions carefully.
wordCards.example_sentence: The shelter helps homeless families find a safe place to stay.
distractor_meanings: having a very large and beautiful home
moving to a different home each year
owning two homes in different cities

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: not paying enough attention; making mistakes because you are not careful
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: care | less. Base word 'care' + '-less.' Silent 'e' in 'care' is kept. Pair with 'careful' to show -ful / -less contrast. Phonetically regular.
wordCards.example_sentence: A careless mistake cost him five points on the test.
distractor_meanings: paying very close attention to details
taking extra time to check your work
nervous about making a mistake

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: without the strength or ability to do anything about a situation
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: pow | er | less. Base word 'power' + '-less.' Pairs directly with 'powerful.' Stress on first syllable. Useful for literature and history discussions about characters and events.
wordCards.example_sentence: She felt powerless to stop the argument.
distractor_meanings: having more strength than anyone else
not caring about what happens
very tired after a long day of work

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: easy and pleasant to read; clear enough to be read
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: read | a | ble. Base word 'read' + '-able.' Drop-e rule does not apply here — 'read' has no final silent 'e.' 'ea' = /ee/. Direct ELA vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: Her handwriting is much more readable now.
distractor_meanings: too long to finish in one sitting
written for adults and very hard to follow
not worth reading because it is boring

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: giving a feeling of ease and relaxation; not causing pain or worry
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: com | fort | a | ble. Often reduced in speech to three syllables: COMF-ter-ble. Base word 'comfort' + '-able.' The 'o' in 'comfort' is a schwa. Common spelling challenge word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The new chair in the library is very comfortable.
distractor_meanings: causing a lot of pain and discomfort
very loud and hard to sit near
too small to use properly

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: so good or unusual that it deserves to be noticed and talked about
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: re | mark | a | ble. 're-' + 'mark' + '-able.' Here 're-' intensifies rather than meaning 'again.' The base 'mark' means to notice. Regular.
wordCards.example_sentence: She gave a remarkable performance in the school play.
distractor_meanings: ordinary and seen every single day
very quiet and easy to miss
disappointing and below average

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a person who teaches others
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: teach | er. Base word 'teach' + '-er.' The 'ea' in teach = /ee/. Very transparent agent noun. Perfect anchor word for the '-er' suffix meaning 'one who.'
wordCards.example_sentence: Our teacher explains things in a way that is easy to understand.
distractor_meanings: a person who watches students but does not teach
someone who writes textbooks for school
a person who takes care of a school building

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a person who performs in movies, plays, or TV shows
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: ac | tor. 'Act' (do) + '-or' (one who). Regular. '-or' is the Latin-origin version of '-er.' Good contrast: '-er' (native English) vs. '-or' (Latin). Stress on first syllable.
wordCards.example_sentence: The actor played the villain in the movie.
distractor_meanings: a person who writes scripts for TV shows
someone who directs actors in a film
a person who designs costumes for plays

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a person whose job is to carefully examine things or places
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | spec | tor. 'In-' (into) + 'spect' (look) + '-or' (one who) = one who looks into things. Stress on second syllable. Good for compound morpheme analysis.
wordCards.example_sentence: The fire inspector checked every room for safety hazards.
distractor_meanings: a person who builds new buildings
someone who makes laws for a city
a doctor who works in a hospital

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: in a fast way; with speed
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: quick | ly. Base word 'quick' + '-ly.' Phonetically regular. The 'qu' = /kw/. Great anchor word for '-ly' suffix. Connects to how adverbs modify verbs.
wordCards.example_sentence: She quickly finished her work so she could go outside.
distractor_meanings: in a very slow and careful way
without making any noise at all
in a confused and mixed-up way

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: in a way that is easy to understand or see
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: clear | ly. Base word 'clear' + '-ly.' Phonetically regular. '-ear' = /eer/. Connects to 'unclear' — this word and its opposite can be taught together.
wordCards.example_sentence: Please write your name clearly at the top of the page.
distractor_meanings: in a very hard to see or understand way
very loudly so everyone can hear
in a rushed and messy manner

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: in a way that is correct and without mistakes
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: ac | cu | rate | ly. Base word 'accurate' + '-ly.' Drop-e rule: 'accurate' ends in silent e, but the 'e' is kept before '-ly' (unlike '-able'). Stress on first syllable.
wordCards.example_sentence: The scientist measured the temperature accurately.
distractor_meanings: in a very slow and careful way only
very loudly so the whole room can hear
by guessing without checking any facts

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a person who studies and does science
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: sci | en | tist. 'Science' + '-ist.' 'Sc' before 'i' = /s/ (not /sk/). The 'ie' = /ee/. This word is common but has a tricky spelling — the 'sc' before 'i' is the main challenge.
wordCards.example_sentence: The scientist discovered a new type of bacteria.
distractor_meanings: a person who writes books about animals
someone who teaches science in school
a person who builds science equipment

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a person who takes strong action to create change in society
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: ac | tiv | ist. 'Act' (do) + '-ive' + '-ist' (one who). Multiple suffixes stacked. Stress on first syllable. Key word for social studies: civil rights, environmental topics.
wordCards.example_sentence: The young activist spoke at the town hall meeting.
distractor_meanings: a person who avoids getting involved in issues
someone who writes laws for the government
a person who studies history at a university

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: likely to cause harm or injury
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: dan | ger | ous. Base word 'danger' + '-ous.' No spelling change needed. The '-ous' = /us/. Stress on first syllable. Very common and useful academic and everyday word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Driving too fast is dangerous.
distractor_meanings: completely safe and without any risk
very exciting and fun to try
easy to do without any practice

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: known and recognized by many people
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: fa | mous. Base word 'fame' + '-ous.' Spelling change: drop the final 'e' from 'fame' before '-ous' (fame → famous). The '-ous' = /us/. Common sight word in text.
wordCards.example_sentence: The famous author visited our school library.
distractor_meanings: unknown and hard to find information about
liked by only a small group of people
remembered for doing something wrong

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: showing bravery even when something is difficult or scary
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: cou | ra | geous. Base word 'courage' + '-ous.' Spelling: the 'ge' before '-ous' keeps its soft 'g' sound, so an 'e' is kept (corageous → courageous). Stress on second syllable.
wordCards.example_sentence: The courageous firefighter ran into the burning building.
distractor_meanings: too scared to try anything new
very angry about an unfair situation
careful and slow to make decisions

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: directions that tell you how to do something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: in | struc | tion. 'In-' (into) + 'struct' (build) + '-ion' = act of building into. '-tion' = /shun/. The consonant cluster 'str' is the main decoding challenge.
wordCards.example_sentence: Read the instructions before you begin the test.
distractor_meanings: a list of things students did wrong
a story told by a teacher to the class
a picture that shows what something looks like

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the ability to see; or a picture in your mind of how things could be
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: vi | sion. 'Vis' (see) + '-ion' = the act of seeing. '-sion' = /zhun/ (not /shun/ here — voiced). This is a key phonics point: '-sion' after a vowel or voiced consonant says /zhun/.
wordCards.example_sentence: The leader shared her vision for a better community.
distractor_meanings: the ability to hear very soft sounds
a decision made without thinking first
a plan written down in a notebook

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: approval from someone in charge to do something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: per | mis | sion. '-sion' after 'ss' = /shun/. The double 's' comes from the root 'miss' + the suffix '-ion.' Very high-frequency school word.
wordCards.example_sentence: She asked for permission to use the computer.
distractor_meanings: a note explaining why you were absent
a list of rules you need to follow
a reward given for good behavior

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a statement about what you think will happen in the future
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: pre | dic | tion. 'Pre-' (before) + 'dict' (say) + '-ion.' '-tion' = /shun/. Morpheme chain is transparent. High utility in science and ELA for reading strategies.
wordCards.example_sentence: The meteorologist's prediction about rain turned out to be wrong.
distractor_meanings: a summary of what happened in a story
an explanation for why something occurred
a question about something you do not understand

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: an arrangement to receive something regularly, like a magazine or service, often for a fee
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: sub | scrip | tion. 'Sub-' (under/up to) + 'script' (write) + '-ion' = the act of writing under (your name). '-tion' = /shun/. Great for media literacy discussions.
wordCards.example_sentence: My family has a subscription to a streaming service.
distractor_meanings: a one-time purchase at a store
a letter written to a business or government
a plan for saving money over time

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a complete change from one thing into something very different
wordCards.decoding_notes: Five syllables: trans | for | ma | tion. 'Trans-' + 'form' + '-ation.' '-ation' = /ay-shun/. Good example of stacking morphemes. Stress on the '-a-' syllable. Science and ELA word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The transformation of the caterpillar was amazing to observe.
distractor_meanings: a very small and gradual change over time
the act of moving something from place to place
a decision to keep things exactly the same

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: when two or more people or things affect each other
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: in | ter | ac | tion. 'Inter-' + 'act' + '-ion.' '-tion' = /shun/. Long word but fully analyzable. Stress on third syllable. Science (chemical interaction) and social word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The interaction between the two chemicals caused a reaction.
distractor_meanings: a decision made without talking to others
a written plan for a group project
a report about what happened in an experiment

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the way something is shaped or arranged; the process of forming something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: for | ma | tion. 'Form' (shape) + '-ation' = act of shaping. '-ation' = /ay-shun/. Common in science (rock formation, cloud formation) and sports.
wordCards.example_sentence: The football team lined up in their formation.
distractor_meanings: the act of breaking something apart
a written plan created for a group
the process of carrying things from place to place

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a collection of work that shows what you have done or can do
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: port | fo | li | o. Contains the root 'port' (carry) + 'folio' (sheet/page). A portfolio is something that carries your pages. Stress on second syllable: por-FOL-io.
wordCards.example_sentence: She put her best essays in her writing portfolio.
distractor_meanings: a notebook where you take notes during class
a single piece of work given to a teacher
a test that covers many different subjects

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to make a guess about something without knowing all the facts
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: spec | u | late. 'Spec' (look) + '-ulate' (process suffix). Looking around to form a guess. Silent 'e' at the end. Stress on first syllable. Academic discussion word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Scientists can only speculate about what caused the extinction.
distractor_meanings: to know something for certain based on proof
to look at something very carefully and closely
to carry out an experiment to find an answer

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: an impressive and dramatic sight or display
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: spec | ta | cle. 'Spect' (look) + '-acle' (thing). Something worth looking at. Stress on first syllable. The '-cle' ending = /kul/. Connects to 'spectacular.'
wordCards.example_sentence: The fireworks show was quite a spectacle.
distractor_meanings: a very boring and ordinary event
a list of things to look at in a museum
a competition between two groups of people

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a written or spoken account of what something looks like or what happened
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: de | scrip | tion. 'De-' + 'script' (write) + '-ion.' '-tion' = /shun/. Noun form of 'describe.' High-frequency ELA word: descriptive writing, character description.
wordCards.example_sentence: Write a description of the setting in the first chapter.
distractor_meanings: a list of reasons why something happened
an argument about a topic you disagree with
a question asked to get more information

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a test performance where you show your singing, acting, or other talent
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: au | di | tion. 'Aud' (hear) + '-ition' (act of) = act of hearing someone perform. '-tion' = /shun/. The 'au' = /aw/. Great vocabulary for music and drama contexts.
wordCards.example_sentence: She practiced every day before her audition for the play.
distractor_meanings: a final performance after being chosen for a role
a class where students learn to sing
a room where actors wait before going on stage

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a leader who has total control and does not allow others to have power or vote
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: dic | ta | tor. 'Dict' (say/speak) + '-ator' (one who does repeatedly). Stress on first syllable. Critical social studies vocabulary. Connects to 'dictate' and 'dictatorship.'
wordCards.example_sentence: The dictator controlled all the newspapers in the country.
distractor_meanings: a leader who is chosen by a fair election
a person who teaches others how to speak
a judge who makes decisions for a court

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to change the way something is organized or built
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: re | struc | ture. 're-' (again) + 'struct' (build) + '-ure.' The cluster 'str' is the main challenge. Silent 'e' at the end. Business, government, and science word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The company decided to restructure its departments.
distractor_meanings: to completely destroy something and start over
to keep everything organized and the same
to write a new plan without changing anything

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: too quiet to be heard
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: in | au | di | ble. 'In-' (not) + 'aud' (hear) + '-ible' = not able to be heard. Good contrast with 'audible.' The 'au' = /aw/. Stress on second syllable.
wordCards.example_sentence: Her whisper was inaudible over the noise of the crowd.
distractor_meanings: too loud to listen to comfortably
easy to hear from a long distance away
very pleasant and enjoyable to listen to

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a formal meeting where people gather to discuss ideas or share information
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: con | fer | ence. 'Con-' (together) + 'fer' (carry/bring) + '-ence.' Carry together = bring together. Stress on first syllable: CON-fer-ence. Common school and professional word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The teacher asked my parents to come to a conference.
distractor_meanings: a test given at the end of a school year
a notebook used to keep track of school work
a report written about a student's progress

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: something that gets in the way and stops things from working properly
wordCards.decoding_notes: Five syllables: in | ter | fer | ence. 'Inter-' (between) + 'fer' (carry) + '-ence.' To carry between = to get in the middle. Stress on third syllable: in-ter-FER-ence. Science and ELA word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Radio interference made it hard to hear the station clearly.
distractor_meanings: a strong signal that makes something easier to hear
a connection between two electronic devices
a device that carries sound from one place to another

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to send goods or products to another country to be sold
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: ex | port. 'Ex-' (out) + 'port' (carry) = carry out. Stress shifts: EX-port (noun) vs. ex-PORT (verb). Pairs with 'import' — teach as opposites.
wordCards.example_sentence: The country exports millions of tons of wheat each year.
distractor_meanings: to bring products in from another country
to store goods in a warehouse safely
to manufacture products in a local factory

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the words, sentences, or situation around something that help you understand its meaning
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: con | text. 'Con-' (together) + 'text' (weave, from Latin texere). Woven together. The '-xt' final cluster can be tricky: /kst/. Extremely high-utility reading strategy word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Use the context clues to figure out the meaning of that word.
distractor_meanings: the title and author listed at the top of a page
a dictionary that lists word definitions
the pictures that go along with a story

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the act of looking at your writing again and improving it
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: re | vi | sion. 're-' (again) + 'vis' (see) + '-ion.' '-sion' after a vowel = /zhun/. Relates to 'revise.' Writing process vocabulary — students use this word in ELA.
wordCards.example_sentence: The revision made her essay much clearer.
distractor_meanings: the first draft written without any planning
a grade given to a student at the end of a unit
a list of errors to correct on a final exam

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: something that breaks up or disturbs normal activity
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: dis | rup | tion. 'Dis-' (apart) + 'rupt' (break) + '-ion.' '-tion' = /shun/. Long final cluster -rupt before -ion requires careful blending. Common classroom and tech word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The fire alarm caused a major disruption to the school day.
distractor_meanings: something that helps a class run more smoothly
a new rule created to prevent problems
a plan for what to do during an emergency

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to change something in order to improve it
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: re | form. 're-' (again) + 'form' (shape) = shape again. Phonetically regular. Stress shifts slightly depending on use. Important social studies and government vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: The students asked the school board to reform the lunch policy.
distractor_meanings: to remove something that is already working well
to keep rules exactly the same as before
to write down what happened at a meeting

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the act of sending in or handing over something
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: sub | mis | sion. 'Sub-' (under) + 'miss' (send) + '-ion.' '-sion' = /shun/. Double 's' from 'miss' + '-ion.' Academic and professional word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The deadline for submission of the project is Monday.
distractor_meanings: the act of checking someone else's work
a schedule that shows when things are due
a decision made by a committee after a vote

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the way something is built or organized; also a building or framework
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: struc | ture. 'Struct' (build) + '-ure.' The initial cluster 'str' and the '-ture' ending (pronounced /cher/) are the main challenges. Very high frequency in all content areas.
wordCards.example_sentence: The structure of a paragraph includes a topic sentence and details.
distractor_meanings: a drawing or map of a building
a list of rules for how to behave
a story that has a beginning and an end

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: small or light enough to be carried easily
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: port | a | ble. 'Port' (carry) + '-able' (able to be). Regular. Unstressed middle vowel is a schwa: /uh/. Great for reinforcing both 'port' root and '-able' suffix in one word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Students carried portable chargers in their backpacks.
distractor_meanings: too big and heavy to move anywhere
needing electricity to work properly
designed to stay in one place forever

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a particular arrangement of people or things
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: for | ma | tion. 'Form' + '-ation.' '-ation' = /ay-shun/. Spelling: the 'a' in '-ation' is long. Common in science (rock formation, storm formation) and sports contexts.
wordCards.example_sentence: The marching band moved into a new formation.
distractor_meanings: the act of breaking apart a solid object
a type of writing that describes a place
a test that checks how well students can run

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: related to the sense of hearing
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: au | di | to | ry. 'Aud' (hear) + '-itory' (relating to). 'au' = /aw/. The unstressed final syllable '-ry' = /ree/. Useful in science and special education contexts.
wordCards.example_sentence: The student has strong auditory memory and learns best by listening.
distractor_meanings: related to the sense of sight and seeing
able to move quickly and without effort
connected to a person's memory for written words

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: likely to burst out suddenly and with force
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: e | rup | tive. 'Rupt' (break) + '-ive' (tending to). The cluster '-rupt' before '-ive' requires attention. Science word especially useful in geology and earth science.
wordCards.example_sentence: The geologist studied the eruptive activity of the volcano.
distractor_meanings: moving slowly and steadily over many years
related to the flow of water through rock
tending to build up layers gradually

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to carry products out of a country to sell abroad
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: ex | port. 'Ex-' (out) + 'port' (carry). When used as a verb, stress falls on second syllable: ex-PORT. Economics and geography word. Pair with 'import' for contrast.
wordCards.example_sentence: Brazil exports large amounts of coffee every year.
distractor_meanings: to purchase items from a foreign country
to store products inside a national warehouse
to carry goods within the borders of one country

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to spell a word the wrong way
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: mis | spell. 'Mis-' (wrongly) + 'spell.' Double 's' because 'mis-' ends in 's' and 'spell' starts with 's.' Very relevant school word — connects to student experience directly.
wordCards.example_sentence: It is easy to misspell words when you are writing quickly.
distractor_meanings: to write a word using very small letters
to use a word in the wrong sentence
to forget to include a word in your writing

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to understand something the wrong way; to get the wrong idea
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: mis | un | der | stand. 'Mis-' (wrongly) + 'understand.' Long compound word — break it into parts: mis + understand. Phonetically accessible once base word is known.
wordCards.example_sentence: He misunderstood the directions and did the wrong assignment.
distractor_meanings: to clearly know what someone is asking you to do
to ask a question when you are not sure
to pretend you understand when you do not

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: writing that is about real people, events, or facts — not made up
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: non | fic | tion. 'Non-' (not) + 'fiction.' '-tion' = /shun/. 'Fic' comes from Latin 'fingere' (make up). Not made-up = nonfiction. Essential ELA genre vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: The nonfiction book about sharks taught me many new facts.
distractor_meanings: a story about imaginary people and places
a book with made-up events that could be real
writing that includes both facts and fantasy

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: the round of a competition just before the final
wordCards.decoding_notes: Four syllables: sem | i | fi | nal. 'Semi-' (half) + 'final.' 'Semi-' means half or partly. Stress on the third syllable: sem-i-FI-nal. Sports and competition context. Connect to 'semicircle.'
wordCards.example_sentence: Our team won the semifinal and will now play for the championship.
distractor_meanings: the very last game in a tournament
the very first round of a competition
a practice game played before a real match

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: including or involving many different cultures and backgrounds
wordCards.decoding_notes: Five syllables: mul | ti | cul | tur | al. 'Multi-' (many) + 'cultural.' 'Multi-' is from Latin multus. Stress on third syllable. Social studies, SEL, and community vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: The multicultural festival celebrated traditions from many countries.
distractor_meanings: belonging to only one specific culture
organized by a single country or nation
focused on ancient customs no longer practiced

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: able to speak two languages
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: bi | lin | gual. 'Bi-' (two) + 'lingual' (language, from Latin lingua). The 'gu' in 'lingual' = /gw/. Stress on second syllable. Personal identity and language arts vocabulary.
wordCards.example_sentence: The bilingual teacher can teach in both English and Spanish.
distractor_meanings: able to speak only one language very well
someone who is learning their first language
a person who has difficulty learning any language

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: happening or existing after a war
wordCards.decoding_notes: Two syllables: post | war. 'Post-' (after) + 'war.' Phonetically regular. Contrast with 'prewar.' 'Post-' (after) vs. 'pre-' (before) is a valuable paired lesson. History and social studies word.
wordCards.example_sentence: The postwar years brought many changes to the country.
distractor_meanings: happening during the middle of a conflict
describing events just before a war begins
relating to a time of peace with no conflict at all

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: to take action against something in order to reduce or stop its effect
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: coun | ter | act. 'Counter-' (against) + 'act' (do). To do against something. Phonetically regular. Science (counteract poison) and social studies (counteract a policy) word.
wordCards.example_sentence: Doctors gave medicine to counteract the effects of the venom.
distractor_meanings: to make the effects of something much stronger
to carefully study how something works
to write a plan to deal with a future problem

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: wrong or improper behavior, especially by someone in a trusted role
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: mis | con | duct. 'Mis-' (wrongly) + 'conduct' (behavior). As a noun, stress is on the first syllable: MIS-con-duct. Important for civics, law, and school community discussions.
wordCards.example_sentence: The coach was removed from the team for misconduct.
distractor_meanings: behavior that is praised and rewarded by others
a plan for how students should act at school
a meeting where students discuss their goals

wordCards.student_friendly_meaning: a document written by hand or an author's draft before it is printed
wordCards.decoding_notes: Three syllables: man | u | script. 'Manu' (hand, Latin manus) + 'script' (write). A document written by hand. Connects to 'manual.' The '-pt' at the end: 't' is sounded, unlike some '-pt' endings.
wordCards.example_sentence: Historians found an ancient manuscript in the library vault.
distractor_meanings: a book that has been printed and sold in stores
a short message written on a card
a speech delivered from memory without notes
